Abstract#1: Tape contains unidentified music, often distorted or dissonant, including various chanting and singing.
Note#1: 00:00 Recording begins, there is static and crackle noises throughout the recording; 00:18 A woman’s voice begins to sing the line “God is a lie, magic is afoot” repeatedly. She switches the lyrics and sings “God is afoot, magic is a lie” and “magic never dies.” The woman continues to sing about magic, God, and man. An acoustic guitar is played in the background throughout the song; 02:00 The tempo picks up and the guitar is played more aggressively. The lyrics continue to sing about magic and the way people use it; 03:40 The song repeats the same lyrics from the beginning, “God is a lie, magic is afoot” and sound effects have been utilized for the woman’s voice to make it sound like it is reverberating. 04:30 The recording changes to a new song. A choir of people sing or chant in the distance. The lyrics are hard to decipher but it sounds religious in theme. Soft drums play in the background; 06:30 A man talks over the choir and he sounds like a religious priest asking the audience to “come”; 08:00 A new recording begins with a drum beat. A man sings about “our father God in heaven” and “the day of reckoning,” as well as other religious lyrics, while the same group that chanted in the previous recording sings “Amen” after the man finishes his lines; 12:18 A new recording begins with a man singing loudly. The lyrics are difficult to decipher. The same group, or choir, from the previous recordings sing in the background. The choir in the background provides various harmonies with their voices while men sing over the choir; 20:22 The recording stops and the same man begins to sing without the choir; 22:25 The choir begins to sing again in the background with the man; 26:15 The recording stops momentarily and then a person continues to sing religious hymns with an instrument playing along; 30:56 Recording stops and the choir of people begin to sing or chant the same thing repeatedly; 38:36 Recording stops and changes to a band playing a rock song. There is a guitar, drums, tambourine, bass guitar, keyboard or synthesizer, and various other instruments played throughout the song. A man begins to sing and there are backup singers in the background; 40:40 Recording stops and a new song begins. A sound effect that resembles wind is played. Drums and other instruments begin to play; 43:20 A guitar solo plays over the rest of the instruments; 51:10 The same song continues with another guitar solo; 01:02:53 The same song continues with another guitar solo; 01:04:30 Recording stops and another song starts. An electric guitar quickly plays a solo; 01:06:55 Recording stops and a synthesizer or guitar is played periodically.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Title from film reads "4 Friends in Search of Somewhen." Photographer, possibly Bonnie Rochetto. Includes footage of men and women in costumes walking on a hill and posing in a cemetary and near a junk pile. A woman, possibly Sandra, wears an embroidered robe with mirrored sun on forehead. Ann Roy wears black and walks with a small boy. Two men wear wolf and bird masks. End card reads "EEEP Foundation"
Note#1: 00:00 Opening title card reads “4 Friends in Search of Somewhen.”; 00:18 Scene shows silhouettes of people standing on the horizon. They wear hats and capes. 00:53 Close-up view of the people walking through a site that appears to be a mine or someplace under construction. First, there is a woman, possibly Sandra, wearing a light pink outfit walking with someone wearing a white robe with a mask that resembles a bird. Next, another woman, Ann Roy, is dressed in black and walks with a young child. A person wearing a mask that looks like a wolf walks behind the woman and the child; 01:47 Close-up view of the wolf mask. The camera zooms into the open mouth of the mask; 01:54 The woman in the pink robe stands in a cemetery while a man sets the wolf mask up on a ledge of a memorial. He then helps the woman up on the top of the ledge; 02:39 All four people pose in front of a pile of scrap metal, two of them wearing the bird and wolf masks. The woman wearing the pink robe also wears a piece of jewelry that resembles a sun with a mirror in the middle. The camera zooms towards the mirror; 03:12 Close-up views of dandelions. People run through the fields of the cemetery; 03:49 A shadow of two hands join over a paper sculpture of a red and yellow flower. Closing credits read “EEEP Foundation.”

Place Created#1: Larkspur (Marin, California, United States, North America) (inhabited place)
Abstract#1: Title from film container. Spider Duncan Christopher does a tarot reading for Alice Cooke Kent, which he describes as "New Tarot for the Aquarian Age."  Recorded in Kentfield, California. Includes possibly the voice of Alice C. Kent.
Note#1: Interviewer is Spider Duncan Christopher: 00:00 Christopher introduces the interviewee as Alice Cook Kent on October 16, 1990. Christopher introduces the topic as a reading for “the new tarot for the aquarian age” and invites the listener to enter “the royal maze and the map of the psyche.”; 01:05 Christopher proceeds to reveal all the tarot cards in the position that Kent chose. He talks about the “knower” card. Christopher talks about revelations he had from previous readings and dives deeper into the “I am force principle.” He also states the “’t’ force is the cross of matter and spirit in a single reality.” He continues to talk about the symbolism of the cross as it relates to his interpretations for God’s “four room races of man” and spells out “W-O-R-D” meaning “white, oriental, red, and dark” and how the races are located throughout the north, south, east and west positions of the world according to the cross; 04:27 Christopher continues to look at other tarot cards such as the doer and mentions Kent is a Gemini and white woman who is masculine and powerful on the outside and feminine on the inside; 05:28 Christopher reveals other cards that relate to the body, conscious next step, ego of the individual, and mask or projected goal; 06:15 Christopher talks about the cards related to Kent’s functions such as thinking, feeling, emotions, and sensation. He mentions there is some interference from the “south pole of [her] feelings” because of negative thinking. Christopher asks Kent if he can facilitate a healing to help her through her thinking and express her feelings; 08:10 Christopher talks about how dominant her intuition, thinking, and sensation is and how her north pole is dominating her south pole where the thinking is dominating her feeling; 09:50 Christopher talks about Kent’s “karma, heredity, and change”; 10:42 Christopher talks about the cards that relate to idealism and consequences. He also talks about self-mastery and completion; 11:10 Christopher talks about the four energies; 12:05 Christopher lists seven major trumps Kent has in her tarot cards. He states she also has one royal trump that stems from childhood and the healing of her feelings; 13:24 Christopher talks about Kent’s couplings from her cards and the theory of numbers working to provide her tarot reading. He talks about the doer card again; 27:00 Christopher talks about the time him and Kent met. He relates their encounter to the alignment of certain planets such as Jupiter; 28:30 Christopher talks about the “seven of stones” and an awakening on a physical level; 49:35 Christopher talks about Kent’s conscious next step. He mentions Kent creates an ambivalence trying to switch back and forth to make people happy. Christopher tells Kent to work on her balance of the spiritual and material worlds; 01:01:00 Christopher revisits the concept of “I am” and “the one.” He talks about the history of tarot cards. He also states there is only one universal mind, and the only truth is love; 01:13:20 Kent talks about her fascination with the citadel and all the different religions and their teachings; 01:21:50 Kent asks Christopher if addictions are represented in the tarot cards. They talk about Kent as a perfectionist and how she was conditioned into that; 01:25:15 Christopher talks about our perception, love, and fear. He spells out F-E-A-R as “false evidence appearing real” and relates it back to Kent’s attempt at separating herself from her addictions; 01:27:48 Christopher talks about Kent’s transition from one state to another and wraps up Kent’s tarot card reading; 01:31:19 Christopher sends loving, healing energy to Kent’s south pole so that she can heal and work on her emotions. Kent talks about how it is socially unacceptable to cry in public but watched people cry at the airport as family members departed.
Subject Title#1: The New Tarot - The Tarot For The Aquarian Age

Place Created#1: Larkspur (Marin, California, United States, North America) (inhabited place)
Abstract#1: Title from film container. Spider Duncan Christopher does a tarot reading Ann Roy, which he describes as "New Tarot for the Aquarian Age."  Recorded in Kentfield, California. Includes possibly the voice of Ann Roy.
Note#1: Interviewer is Spider Duncan Christopher: 00:00 Christopher introduces the interviewee as Ann Roy on October 19th, 1990. Christopher introduces the topic as a reading for “the new tarot for the aquarian age” and invites Roy to enter “the royal maze” and “the map of her psyche.”; 01:35 Christopher talks through the various cards Roy chose that relate to the body, unconscious, conscious next step, ego of the individual, and mask or projected goal. Christopher also talks about the cards related to Roy’s functions such as thinking, feeling, emotions, and sensation. He mentions that Roy’s intuition is dominant. Roy asks if we can think of intuition as water and emotions as fire. Roy mentions there is no negative interference between her emotions and sensations; 04:08 Christopher talks about her karma cards and her future and success; 09:36 Christopher talks about the balance Roy has between the male, female, and child. He also talks about “the you”; 10:50 Roy asks Christopher to explain the relation between water and intuition again. He talks about how we perceive the present and future; 19:45 Roy talks about a visionary experience she had earlier with bears. Christopher talks about how his name “Spider” comes from a tarot card; 23:10 Roy asks Christopher about the planets associated with her tarot cards. Christopher talks about her intuitive gifts from the cards; 27:10 Christopher talks about love and fear and the concept of error as “err-or” which can be corrected; 31:17 Christopher talks about the hanging-man card Roy has in her readings. He admits it is the hardest to interpret but can be seen as the reversal of the male and female energy, as well as redemption; 35:45 Roy asks Christopher about the card with a hand depicted on it. Christopher believes it has to do with an extension of feeling; 37:09 Roy talks about the “I am force principle”; 39:00 Roy tells Christopher about a family who had a son that was an alcoholic and had recently died. Roy relates the story to a time of great change and sacrifice; 42:30 Christopher and Roy talk about grief and Christopher brings up a point about Roy being white and how white people want to be rational or logical soldiers who are in control while Black people want to dance and party. Christopher continues to relate the tarot card depicted with fire to white people and the struggle they feel from the conditioning of their white skin versus the internal nature they have to feel; 49:40 Christopher asks Roy to write a letter to her father and mother, although deceased, as a way to heal. He instructs her to write down her feelings and memories from the perspective of herself as a child. He asks Roy to sign each letter by stating “I absolutely unconditionally love you” she then must reread the letter the next day from the point of view of her parents; 58:40 Christopher and Roy talk about the history of the word “man” and “mankind” and how much weight and meaning is put on the word man versus woman; 01:03:00 Christopher and Roy wrap up the tarot reading session.
Subject Title#1: The New Tarot - The Tarot For The Aquarian Age

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Recording of conversation between Ann Roy and possibly Margaret Fielder, likely discussing the 1975 World Conference on Women in Mexico City. Topics include Betty Friedan, Gloria Steinman, the CIA, Ms. Magazine, Patty Hearst, anti-semitism, and division among leftist and feminist organizations. They discuss how the Movimiento de Liberacion de la Mujer (Women's Liberation Movement) boycotted the Conference, arguing that some politicians, especially men, wanted the conference in Mexico as a tourist attraction and to garner support of the United Nations, while shutting out Mexican women and Mexican domestic issues. See also 41-10, "Ann and Margaret"
Note#1: [Cataloger’s note: Loud static noise from tape plays throughout and the voices are very quiet] 00:00 Two women, Ann, and Margaret, talk to each other about various topics, mostly including the 1975 World Conference on Women in Mexico City. 02:00 Margaret talks about something she has learned and a phone call; 09:00 Margaret talks about an assumption that some people are the CIA. They continue to talk about the Mexican government and politics in general; 16:10 Ann brings up a topic about journalists. Margaret responds with an example of hearing about the women in Chile banging on pots and pans and knowing exactly what was happening in Chile despite what journalism was writing or reporting; 26:00 Margaret talks about the culture and social conditions of women at the time.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Recording of conversation between Ann Roy and possibly Margaret Fielder, likely discussing the 1975 World Conference on Women in Mexico City. Topics include Betty Friedan, Gloria Steinman, the CIA, Ms. Magazine, Patty Hearst, anti-semitism, and division among leftist and feminist organizations. They discuss how the Movimiento de Liberacion de la Mujer (Women's Liberation Movement) boycotted the Conference, arguing that some politicians, especially men, wanted the conference in Mexico as a tourist attraction and to garner support of the United Nations, while shutting out Mexican women and Mexican domestic issues. See also 41-09, "Ann and Margaret"
Note#1: [Cataloger’s note: Voices are very quiet throughout and it makes it difficult to decipher what is being said] 00:00 Ann talks about the dynamics of men and women at the time. She continues to talk about an international, feminist conference of women joining together from places such as Vietnam and South America to demonstrate to the press that feminism is not a counter-revolution, women stand in solidarity and their concerns are real and reasonable; 4:45 Ann talks about the chairman of the feminism conference, [Nadina Markova?] who was on the stage at this conference and who started this group. She was fired from several jobs for being too feminist which is why the group was started; 17:00 Margaret and Ann talk about how people interrupt each other when something bothers them during a conversation. Margaret and Ann feel like they are criticizing each other and they both attempt to clarify their positions with each other; 23:00 Margaret shares something about Ann that she feels is wrong and socially conditioned. She also talks about cultural imperialism and Ann and Margaret talk about Ann being American; 29:30 Margaret admits her and Ann are close enough to be able to talk about their different perspectives without putting each other down. Margaret talks about the word feminism in other countries. Ann responds about American interference in other countries. The women attempt to agree that it is only sisters that matter, not the country you come from; 33:00 Ann tells a story about a group of cheerleaders led by a young man. He exclaims "Bautista, no habla español!" repeatedly.

Title#1: Ann Roy and Barbara Simon, Sex and Death
Abstract#1: Title from film container. Reel contains panning images over series of paintings involving collage, flowers, women's bodies, and religious imagery, some in ornate frames. Reel ends with footage of Ann Roy posing with woman, possibly Tulsa gallery owner and later UFO investigator Barbara Simon Bartholic.
Note#1: 00:00 Camera pans over the surface of a painting showing religious imagery. There are figures of people with large eyes and smiles and showing their teeth throughout; 00:31 Camera zooms up towards another painting of a potted plant with three flowers that look like calla lilies or peace lilies. Scene changes back to the previous painting of the people with the large mouths. There is a close-up view of a person laying in the fetal position. The camera repeatedly zooms in and out of an image of a mouth pasted over a woman’s genitalia; 01:19 Scene changes to a new painting of a face. The camera pans down to a small portrait of a naked woman with other figures around her. There is another portrait of a person’s face with their tongue sticking out. The camera zooms in and out repeatedly to the mouths on each of the paintings; 02:58 Scene changes to show Ann Roy posing with another woman who might be Barbara Simon Bartholic. The camera zooms in on their faces and mouths. Film ends.

Place Created#1: Cuernavaca (Morelos, Mexico, North and Central America) (inhabited place)
Abstract#1: Title from film container. Recordings likely from a course by Ann Roy at Center for Intercultural Documentation (CIDOC) in Cuernavaca, Mexico, possibly on Women in Mexico. Ann Roy tells an extended story about two young sisters she knew in Marfil, Guanajuato, Mexico in the 1960s - Bola and Concha - who both became pregnant before marriage. She describes it as an illustration of how little women are taught about sex and conception in Mexican village culture. Students ask questions and interject with their own thoughts and experiences, sometimes overlapping. Discussions include Mexican customs of chaperoned courtship and marriage agreeements between families, the difference between civil and religious marriage, Mexican compulsory military service, stigmas of divorce and single motherhood, and the strictness of Mexican and Cuban families. In the last clip, Ann Roy talks about perceptions of men and women in Mexican culture, machismo, women who kill their husbands, a lack of rehabilitation services for women in prison, and Aztec culture as one of the first patriarchal cultures.  Recording starts and ends in progress.
Note#1: 00:00 Ann talks about “robada” or “to steal” and relates the term with a situation where parents will not give a young couple permission to marry. Ann continues to explain that in village culture, when a young woman leaves church in the evening she does not go back home with her parents, but either sleeps outside or stays with a relative related to the man. Ultimately, the woman is not allowed to be received back by her parents until she marries; however, Ann explains that the situation is complicated because the woman’s parents are not allowed to agree immediately to marriage or else people might think there is something wrong with the girl, yet the girl must sleep outside until her parents agree to a marriage; 03:00 Ann tells a story about a young couple she knew. The girl, Bola was secretly staying with a boy, Louis, in his room. The mother knew about it and did not say anything while the father was unaware of the situation. After nine months of hiding the girl she became pregnant and Arturo freaked out, blamed the girl, and attempted to give the baby away. Bola did not agree to give the baby away. When the girl was seven months pregnant, Bola and her sister, Concha met two boys from out of town and they walked with the girls in the evening. Louis became jealous and wanted to marry her immediately after disregarding her and the pregnancy; 15:00 The girl marries the other boy instead and did not care about the advice of other people in the village; 15:50 Ann tells the story of another couple, Concha and Jaunito. Concha also becomes pregnant and she had no idea when or how it happened. Ann talks about practicing natural childbirth with Concha and how successful it was; 24:10 Ann talks about going to Tulsa with both Concha and Bola for two months and both the girls are confused and worried about being pregnant again since they have not received their periods. Ann talks about Bola’s husband and how scary it was for him to ask her parents if he could marry her; 29:30 Another woman in the room tells a story about another couple that wanted to get married and the parents refused. The girl ended up getting married and the parents do not know; 31:50 [Cataloger’s note: recording becomes quieter and harder to understand]. Ann offers suggestions to make marriage easier; 36:40 Ann tells a story about her friend, Christina; 47:45 Ann talks about a societal pattern in Mexico regarding the male and female and mentions how the female side is identified with the [Inca?] as losers and the male side is identified with the conquistador as the winners. Ann tells a story about a young man who was close-minded and macho. She continues to say that as a female you are supposed to be passive, open, and will-less versus men who must be aggressive and closed; 55:00 Ann talks about equality between men and women in pre-Columbian civilizations and the value the different functions men and women performed for the civilization as a whole; 58:10 Ann notes that the first big change between preexisting patterns between males and females occurred with the Aztec civilization as they became a male dominated society.
Subject Geographic#1: Marfil (Guanajuato, Mexico, North and Central America) (inhabited place)

Title#1: Baptism, Simon and Lucy/Pablo’s Birthday Truck/Tepoztlan
Abstract#1: Title from film container. Reel contains home movie footage, likely from Tepoztlán, Morelos, Mexico. Scenes include: a man and woman, possibly Simon and Lucy, with baby outside a stone church; same man and woman in a gated patio, where another woman holds the baby and his diaper is changed; an outdoor gathering, likely Pablo's birthday, where men and women drink champagne around a large Dodge pickup truck decorated with flowers; a man, likely Pablo, poses by the truck with two children; birthday cake candles are lit, cake reading "Feliz Cumpleaños Pablo."  Some footage is too dark to identify.
Note#1: 00:00 A large group of people stand outside in Tepoztlán. There is a mother and father, possibly Simon and Lucy, holding a baby; 00:15 People are still gathered outside but it is dark. Although there is no audio, people talk into the camera; 00:38 The father and mother peer through leaves and branches of a tree over a rooftop. The father holds the baby over the rooftop; 00:53 The family is seen walking through a gate on the side of a house. The mother plays with and holds her son in her arms. She also changes his diaper; 01:31 People gather outside their cars which are decorated with flowers and a man, possibly Pablo, stand with two children. A bottle of champagne is popped open. People pass the bottle around and drink from it. 03:09 People light candles on a birthday cake that reads, "Feliz Cumpleaños Pablo." Film ends.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Reel contains footage of a a wedding procession in Tepoztlán, Morales, Mexico. A white woman in veil, possibly Lucy, walks down the street with bearded men holding incense. Wedding guests, local people, and children look on. Ann Roy appears around 1:00, carrying a silver cup and platter. Reel includes close-up footage of wedding guests outdoors, many dancing and playing drums and percussion instruments. The bride and groom, possibly Simon, offer drinks to guests and on-looking children from the silver cup.
Note#1: 00:00 Close-up of a bride, possibly Lucy, walking down an aisle. She is wearing a white veil and dress. Children wearing blue and white outfits accompany the woman; 00:40 A procession of the wedding party and guests follow the bride into the chapel; 01:07 The camera zooms in on Ann Roy carrying a ceremonial chalice and plate while following the bride and groom, possibly Simon. People from the wedding continue to mingle; 01:54 People play various instruments outside amongst the wedding guests; 02:15 The bride holds the silver cup, which may serve as a loving cup, seen in previous footage. The bride and groom kiss and dance outside along with the live music being played. The bride passes around the silver "loving" cup and several wedding guests drink from it. Film ends.

Title#1: Cholula 1 of 2: Patty B. and John S. Amazon, Patty B
Abstract#1: Title from film container. A woman, possibly Patty Burris, with face painted, encounters a series of men in a garden. She battles a bearded man with sticks, dances with two other men, then dances alone.
Note#1: 00:00 A woman, possibly named Patty Burris, poses with a cigarette and paint on her face; 00:24 Patty and a man reenact a battle scene. She is now wearing the red cape and spreads her arms wide open while holding onto the cape. She then does a dance utilizing the cape; 03:47 Film ends.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Men and women pose in various animal masks and costumes. Great Pyramid of Cholula visible in background.
Note#1: 00:00 View of fields and the surrounding landscape in Mexico. The camera zooms in on the Great Pyramid of Cholula, visible in background, as well as the plants in the foreground; 00:11 Scene changes to show two men pacing back and forth while wearing animal masks. The man wearing floral patterned shorts and a lizard mask kneels on the ground. He lowers a small, green plastic gun and wooden cross to the ground. He then raises the cross towards the sky. The front of the cross is painted with red and yellow paint and reads, “ARISE” and “DEVIATE.” The other man with the wolf mask continues to pace back and forth behind the man with the lizard mask; 00:50 Another man wearing a bird shaped mask performs a dance while holding stalks of foliage; 01:07 Scene changes to show a woman dancing. She also holds an animal mask. Film ends.

Title#1: Christina and Juan Gustina, Sundance and ballet
Abstract#1: Title from film container. Man and woman, likely Christina and Juan Gustina, in costumes, dance in a field. Their dance involves a circle painted with a symbol. Much of reel's second half of reel is too dark to be identified. Ends with dancers bowing on a stage, where curtain falls.
Note#1: 00:00 Camera zooms in on a circular shaped canvas. It depicts red and yellow stripes with an image of a blue eye in the middle; 00:05 A man and woman, possibly Christina and Juan Gustina, wear costumes and walk through a field as they prepare for a ballet skit. The man lifts the woman up over his head and the woman grabs the round canvas out of a tree. The couple continues to dance with the piece of artwork; 01:24 Film changes to show people dancing but it is very dark and difficult to decipher what else is happening; 02:27 Scene changes to show four women on a stage in black outfits. Another man and woman dressed in white ballet outfits take a bow next to the four women and exit the stage. Film ends.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. A woman and boy hold signs reading "See Through Circus" and "Reality is Eternity in Drag." Reel contains footage of women and maybe men, mostly young, parading and posing in colorful costumes and makeup. One woman holds a sign reading "Local Union Repress-entation"; an older woman wears a sash reading "The Other Mother"; one woman carries a notebook and butterfly net, one dresses as pregnant woman, possibly Virgin Mary. Last, Ann Roy enters wearing a badge and a sash reading "The Other Mother." She holds a sword overhead and lifts a mirror to the camera, which is revealed to have sun and moon drawing on back.
Note#1: 00:00 Film begins with a scene showing the moon in the night sky; 00:04 Ann Roy is shown wearing a police badge stands and stares at the camera; 00:07 Scene changes to show a woman and young boy walking along the sidewalk and holding yellow signs. The boy’s sign reads, “REALITY IS ETERNITY IN DRAG” and the woman’s sign reads, “SEE THROUGH CIRCUS.” Multiple women proceed to line up along the sidewalk and pose in their dresses and costume accessories. As they walk towards the camera one woman holds a sign that reads, “LOCAL UNION, Repress-entation”; 02:40 Ann Roy, shown previously wearing the police badge, walks out towards the pageant with a sword, hand mirror, and sash wrapped around her torso that reads “The Other Mother.” She hands the sword, mirror, and sash over to someone else and unbuttons her shirt to show a purple and white tie-dye tank top; 03:14 A man walks out on the sidewalk with the sword and the sign attached to the sword that read, “REALITY IS ETERNITY.” He points the sword towards the camera and walks into the frame. Film ends.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Reel contains footage of a woman of color in a black leotard, dancing or posing in a garden. She places a mirrored sun on a tree and removes a long piece of shiny fabric, which she wraps around herself in various ways. Possibly a depiction of the story of Eve.
Note#1: 00:00 Film begins with a view of leaves and fruit from a tree. Silver, shiny fabric is wrapped around the branches and trunk of the tree and vaguely resembles a snake or vine in the tree; 00:28 A woman dressed in all black clothing lays in the grass outside. She sits up and fidgets with bark from the ground; 01:20 The woman walks towards the tree with the fabric in it. At first, she reacts in disgust to the wrapped piece of fabric, which now has a small mirror resembling a sun on it. Her mood suddenly seems to change as she walks backs to the fabric in the tree and shows intimacy towards it; 03:37 The woman takes the fabric from the tree and wraps it around her neck and body. She proceeds to unravel the fabric and drape it over her head and body like a cape or shawl. She continues to perform an interpretive dance with the fabric; 06:51 The woman’s expression quickly changes from intimacy to pain; 07:02 The scene changes to show the woman standing again and holding the fabric over her head and draped around her body while she dances with the shiny fabric; 07:50 Scene changes to show the fabric wrapped around the tree again with the sun shaped mirror. Her eye is reflected in the center of the mirror. Film ends.

Note#1: 00:00 Ann introduces a session she is going to hold during her female consciousness course. Ann talks about a visual exercise the class is going to partake in which each participant represents a female appendage; 01:25 Ann talks about a hat she has from 1895 that she wants each person to experience wearing because it helps the wearer understand more about women and balance. She wants to film each woman’s experience while wearing the hat and other props Ann has; 04:45 Another woman in the course talks about a pageant that the women held and how one woman brought her grandmother’s shoes from China. She continues to talk about the aristocracy of Chinese culture; 09:00 Ann asks the class if they ever heard “whether the left hand of God is dirty or evil?” The class talks back and forth about the topic. One woman mentions her grandmother was born left-handed and was forced to write with her right hand; 15:00 [Cataloger’s note: Other people in the class share their stories but some of them are difficult to decipher.] Ann talks about a family digging a large hole in their backyard for an outhouse; 25:00 Ann poses a question to the class to consider and they have a discussion about it. [Cataloger’s note: Question difficult to understand.]

Note#1: 00:00 Ann talks about Mexico and asks, “what is female consciousness?” She continues to talk about Mesoamerican sacrifices; 02:00 Ann talks about a theory she had, that being, the matriarchy is a projection of the patriarchy. She talks about the patrilineal perception and women rule; 04:00 A person in the class talks about castration and methods for castration; 09:38 Ann talks about the secret mothers know which is when their children “were not.” Ann reflects on her life before becoming a mother and having children; 13:00 Class members talk about cultural traditions regarding male castration. One man talks about the Ethiopian experience and castration; 16:18 Ann talks about studying Spanish and Italian. She considered the construction of the word for “us” or “other” between different languages. The class continues to talk about the concept of “people” as a generic word and “us” as human beings; 26:00 A woman in the class talks about a conversation she had with man and how the man would only vote for a woman in a secondary position, but not in a top position, because “a good woman is all heart and she can’t say no.” Ann expands on this idea and how society has this idea that if a woman goes out on the street alone she is just going to lie down; 28:00 Another woman in the class brings up the topic of rape how women fight during rape. They talk about the ways in which society classifies a situation as rape if the woman has had sex previously, or if women don’t fight then the sex becomes consensual. Another woman brings up the idea of “usual crime” or “normal crime” and police treatment of women when it comes to rape and abortion; 35:05 A man asks Ann a question about writing. Ann talks about writing a piece for Psychology Today that studies the left and right hemispheres of the brain. She relates the right hemisphere to female and the left hemisphere to male and talks about how people write with their right hand versus their left hand; 40:30 The class talks about how women are stereotyped as being hysterical and if a man behaves badly he is told he is acting like a woman; 50:25 Ann talks about how people in the United States finally know what “machismo” means and how it is used. Ann mentions that the young men in Mexico today get upset if they are called macho. The class compares the parallels of the term macho in Mexico to male chauvinist in the United States.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Images of a beach through a walled garden. A man, possibly Carl Fritz, emerges nude from a tub, wearing fishing net and holding up three fingers. He walks nude on the beach, toward the water, where he kneels. With a finger, he draws a symbol in the sand. Close up on his footprints toward the water. He walks into the waves. Abstract images of garden tools and plants. Ann Roy, nude, appears at 4:05, in wood tub with flowers. A beach cemetary. 5:20 Ann Roy appears in head scarf, poses holding up a series of tarot cards. Sunset.
Note#1: 00:00 View of the ocean from the doorway of a walled garden; 00:18 The camera focuses on a small, square tub of water and a man, possibly Carl Fritz, slowly raises his hands and then body out of the water. There is a fish net over his face. He also holds three fingers up on his hand; 00:53 Fritz is naked and walks along the beach and towards the ocean. He kneels in the sand and watches the waves; 01:38 He begins to use his finger to draw a symbol in the sand. It appears to be a circle with two crosses on each side; 02:25 Fritz is now swimming in the ocean; 03:20 The camera zooms in on a chunk of unidentifiable debris and plants; 04:04 The scene changes to show Ann Roy, naked and sitting in a small bath with flowers floating on top of the water. The camera pans to various views of nature; 04:58 The scene changes to show a small cemetery with white grave markers. Ann Roy stands outside the cemetery in a dress. She pulls tarot cards out of her sleeve, fans them out, and holds them up towards the camera. She begins to show individual cards that read: “Mother,” “Feeling,” “Serpent-Que[?],” “Reverse[d?],” “Knower,” and “Reacter”; 06:20 Ann Roy stands in front of the setting sun and looks into the camera. Film ends.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Recording of Ann and Willie Nevin's slideshow, "Travels in Italy." Voice of Ann Roy, with translation to Spanish by possibly Willie Nevin, while music plays.
Note#1: 00:00 Music plays in the beginning. Ann introduces the piece by stating, “Travels in Italy, a magic lantern show.” Ann continues to narrate throughout the recording and a man translates what she is saying in Spanish. The music continues in the background; 7:40 The background music stops, but Ann states the final line of the piece, “In my beginning is my end, in my end is my beginning.” The line is translated to Italian and the recording ends.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Recordings of a casual conversation between Ann Roy and 3-4 other women at her home in Tepoztlán, Morelos, Mexico. Voices sometimes overlap. Speakers include a British woman, Susan; a 20-year-old American woman, Jackie; and a 29-year-old woman, possibly also named Jackie. They discuss implications of grammar and etymology in English and Spanish; moral messages in classic songs and fairy tales; make-up, men who wear make-up, and androgyny; women's magazines and radical feminist publications; politeness as a form of manipulation in Mexican culture; sex and erectile dysfunction; and problems of miscommunication among their group of friends. Ann speaks on having eight godchildren in Marfil, six living; her marriage to John Nevin, and photos and paintings from her time with him, including the Magic Lantern book; her periods of celibacy; giving up her son Willie; and serving as a mother figure to many people in their community. One woman describes her time as a nun in a convent. Another woman talks about her participation in the American Anthropology Association. The recording starts and ends in progress; speed and pitch varies throughout the recording. May continue on tape 41-22, "Night at Ann's 3-4."
Note#1: 00:00 A woman, possibly Ann, talks about the stories of men being betrayed by a faithless woman; 01:00 Another woman in the background asks what it means for men to lose themselves or feel lost. Ann states it is a way for men to say their bad actions are not their fault. They reference a song about a man who lost himself because of an ungrateful woman. Multiple women in the room continue to talk amongst themselves about the dynamic of men and women. Multiple conversations occur at once throughout the recording; 19:00 A woman talks about how she had to reevaluate her opinions on men wearing makeup after she saw Byron wearing it. She continues to say that Byron was in a beautiful moment that made wearing makeup okay for him; 24:40 Another woman in the background, possibly Ann, tells a story about getting cheap chopsticks from San Francisco after buying “authentic” ones from Chinatown. The women continue to talk about the men in Mexico and the Mexican culture of people not telling the truth; 37:00 Ann talks about her first marriage in California and her younger years. The women look through pictures and talk about having children; 43:00 The women talk about [Rampart?], as well as how they enjoy being women but don’t want to conform to all the social constructs and expectations of being a woman and rather just a person; 48:10 The talking cuts out and the song “Cisco Kid” from War plays; 51:13 The song cuts out and the women are talking in the background. The topic of women and betrayal comes up again; 57:00 The women talk about sex, love, and respect for yourself; 01:12:00 A woman talks about a vision she had when another woman walks in and interrupts her train of thought. The women agree to show a symbol to each other to acknowledge their presence when one of them joins so that their visions are not interrupted; 01:25:00 The women talk about family dynamics, children, and how particular families in their group must choose between the “religion of commercialism” and the old culture of religion in Mexico; 01:37:00 The women ask Ann about her book. They also talk about the close connections and energy they receive from each other; 01:44:00 The women talk about the men in their group such as Jack and Marco. They continue to talk about an incident that happened between each other until the recording ends.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Title from film container. Recordings of  Ann Roy and 2-3 other women reading poetry and speaking casually at her home in Tepoztlán, Morelos, Mexico. Voices sometimes overlap. Speakers include a 20-year-old American woman, Jackie, and another woman possibly also named Jackie. Readings include an essay or article on androgyny and David Bowie; a poem by Robin Morgan about Sylvia Plath; "Letter to a Sister Underground" by Robin Morgan; and poetry by Ann Roy from the early 1950s. Ann Roy discusses her interest in poetry and writing, the inspirations for her poetry in Prescott, AZ, Italy and Spain - including the birth of her son Willie, her first divorce, her marriage to John Nevin, and death of her father. The women discuss various people they know from the Center for Intercultural Documentation (CIDOC) in Cuernavaca, Mexico, including the "Monsignor" Ivan Illich. Ann Roy describes seeing a white light the first time she met Illich. Jackie describes her arrival in Mexico, and meeting and bonding with Margaret [Fielder?], who brought her to Ann Roy's house to live. Jackie reads a letter from her mother, who has recently visited Mexico and disapproves of her lifestyle.
Note#1: 00:00 A woman, possibly Ann, reads from a book or passage; 11:45 Ann stops reading and the other women in the room talk amongst themselves; 24:24 Ann reads a letter in the form of a poem, written to her sister; 28:45 Ann reads another poem about masculinity. The women continue to talk amongst themselves about various topics; 39:36 Ann talks about a notebook she wrote in. The content starts with her time in Prescott, Arizona in 1952. Ann was 20 years old when she first got married. She explains her realization or breakthrough of herself and her life after six years of marriage and then leaving her marriage. The notebooks continue through her life; 01:02:00 Ann and the other women continue to talk about their experiences in life such as raising kids and the images of women in culture and society; 01:13:00 Another woman shares a letter from her mother. She talks about her mother visiting her in Mexico and how her mother attempted to convince her to come back and go to school. The women continue to talk about incidents that have happened between their group of friends until the recording ends. Ann offers the women fried bananas.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Children perform a puppet show with hand-made hand puppets. Poster reads "The Fight over the Fountain of Youth.. Production by Scholar's Workshop, 7th Grade, Jan. 1972."  Reel begins with images of children inside a small art classroom and a woman working with the children.
Note#1: 00:00 A class of young students work around various tables; 00:10 Scene changes to show a close-up of an artwork made from aluminum can lids hanging on wire. Scene changes to show another hanging art piece depicting a leaf cut out of metal; 00:23 Children play with hand puppets. The backdrops for the puppets include tree branches and potted plants; 01:30 A woman sews cloth onto the head of a puppet. The scene changes to show a group of children holding signs which introduce their puppet show. The title card reads, “The fight over the fountain of youth.” A little girl holds up a smaller sign that reads, “Production by Scholar’s Workshop.” Another girl holds up a sign that reads, “The 7th grade, Jan. 1972”; 01:53 Scene changes to show some of the children standing behind a small curtain and performing the puppet show. Film ends.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Film contains footage of Ruby Rochetto (a.k.a. Bonnie Rochetto) lying in bed, as if in repose. Room is decorated with flowers and candles, while others gather in red and black. One man is dresseed as a mime while another plays the flute. Continued on Reel 34-16, "Ruby 2 of 2."
Note#1: 00:00 Camera zooms in on Ruby (Bonnie) Rochetto lying on a bed and holding a white calla lily as if in repose. A group of women begin to sit on the bed. There is a tribal mask, flowers and large pieces of fabric hanging over the head of the bed; 01:03 The scene changes to show other women sitting around the bedroom. Two women continue to comfort Ruby; 03:06 A mime appears in the room at the foot of the bed. There is a person playing the flute behind them. Film ends.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Continued from Reel 34-15, "Ruby 1 of 2." Reel contains footage of Ruby Rochetto (a.k.a. Bonnie Rochetto) waving to camera before lying down in VW microbus, as if in a hearse. Two women on horses - one possibly Ann Roy in red robes - wait nearby.
Note#1: 00:00 Ruby (Bonnie) Rochetto smiles and waves from the inside of a Volkswagen Bus before laying on a small bed inside the vehicle; 00:05 Two women sit on horseback, Possibly Ann Roy and Ruby Rochetto; 00:11 The VW Bus is traveling on the road; 00:12 Scene changes to a close-up of a pink flower. Film ends.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Reel contains a quick succession of images, including a man - possibly Simon - holding a Super 8mm film camera, a series of cards reading "Tai Chi" with drawings, a person drawing a star chart, a wall reading "EEEP," and plants and shadows in a garden. Roy appears around 1:30. Reel also includes close-up images of various men with Ann Roy near a stone pyramid - possibly the Temple of the Feather Serpent in Xochicalco, Morelos, Mexico - with a goat standing on top. Reel ends abstract pans across the sky and lanscape and a close-up of man writing letter to "Ma," addressed to "Mrs. O'Brien," possibly signed "John."
Note#1: 00:00 A man, possibly Simon, sits on the ground and pulls out a Super 8mm film camera out of a hat decorated with red, white, and blue stripes; 00:13 Close-up of a person’s hands holding a red sponge. The hands grasp the sponge tightly until all the soap suds protrude out of it; 00:17 Close-up of a rock or paper weight sitting on a handwritten document; 00:23 Film changes and quickly changes scenes showing the close-up of a man’s face with something on his forehead, a drawing, reflection of a tarp over water, exterior view of the tarp and small cards with various handwritten text and drawings. One of the cards reads “Play Me.”; 01:12 Film changes to show someone sketching on paper, possibly Ann Roy; 01:41 People are gathered at a stone pyramid with Roy, possibly Temple of the Feather Serpent in Xochicalco. There is a goat standing at the top of the stairs to the temple; 02:58 Films changes to show a person writing a card or letter while sitting in the grass. The card is addressed to May. The group of people are still at the temple sitting on the ledges of rock. Film ends.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Footage of three young women posing in a cloaks and a homemade mask - likely by artist William Rabon - in a home. The women wear mirrored suns on their foreheads. Reel also includes close-ups on fairy paintings around the room - also by William Rabon - and brief shot of woman made-up as a lion. Ann Roy appears in cloak at 3:34, and later holds a photo album showing another woman. Reel ends with woman removing mask to reveal a Batman sticker on her forehead.
Note#1: 00:00 Film begins by showing a profile view of a girl wearing a costume that includes a thick, blond wig, blue robe, and mask of a woman’s face. The scene changes to show two girls with the costume. One girl controls the face mask, or head, and the other girl is kneeled and hidden by the blue robe and she controls the arms of the character; 01:37 The two girls are now standing on each side of the character and they take turns kissing the face mask on the cheek, as well as posing next to it; 02:14 Close-up of a painting depicting a girl lounging on a crescent moon. Scene changes back and forth between the two girls next to the face mask and the painting; 03:07 The girls are now dressed in the costume and controlling the head and arms again. The film periodically goes dark and the scene reappears to show a different woman wearing the costume; 04:03 Scene changes to show one of the girls wearing an outfit that resembles a lion. The scenes begin to quickly change from different perspectives of paintings and the women. Film ends.

Abstract#1: Side A label reads, "Aranjuez." Tape contains unidentified music tracks, including song "Sisters of Mercy," with Ann Roy. Voice of Ann Roy at 21:36: "Sisters of Mercy. Being a web made by many for the recollection of one. Masks and painting by William Rabon. Play by Patricia [Glossen?] and Mother. Production of the EEEP Foundation. I am the camera." Possibly a soundtrack to accompany "Sisters of Mercy" (Reel 35-3) and "Three Queens" (Reel 35-1) in this collection.
Note#1: 00:00 Sound recording opens with instrumental music playing. A woman begins to sing the lyric “this is a call to the mothers in the earth.” The singer continues to list notable women such as Joan of Arc and Roman goddess, Venus. Background music continues; 01:09 The lyrics stop and a guitar plays along with the tune of the background music; 04:00 The tempo of the music picks up. The instrumentals of the song continue and seem to repeat; 21:09 A new song begins to play. The woman from the beginning of the recording states “Sisters of Mercy, being a web made by many, for the recollection of one. Masks and painting by William Rabon. Play by [Patricia Glossen?] and Mother. Production of the EEEP Foundation.”; 22:54 A man begins to sing with a guitar in the background. A woman joins shortly after and sings along with the man; 27:14 The man and woman stop singing and the instrumental music continues until the end of the recording.

Abstract#1: Title from film container. Three women pose on a chaise lounge in a living room, one as a lion with a mirrored sun on her forehead, Ann Roy in a snake skinned suit, and a woman in black, sometimes veiled, holding a jeweled sword. They hold up mirrors and peacock feathers. Reel also includes footage of the woman preparing their shots and costumes, and pans across artwork and decorative objects in the room, some by artist William Rabon. Later, they are joined by two men and two boys. In the end, Ann Roy holds up a hand mirror to reveal the camera operator, and a toilet flushes.
Note#1: 00:00 Camera pans around a room showing various knickknacks on a shelf and the walls such as a peacock feather, candelabras, and posters; 00:50 A girl dressed as a lion smiles into the camera. She holds a peacock feather and has a small, sun-shaped mirror attached to her forehead; 01:31 Scene changes to show a close-up view of a painting. The camera pans over to Ann Roy holding peacock feathers while the girl in the lion outfit is laying on a red couch. There is another woman wearing a black dress and holding a sword with a handle that looks like a golden cross. She is sitting on the far end of the sofa as well; 04:00 The woman holding the peacock feathers is now sitting on the floor and using a feather to tickle the foot of the woman wearing all black. Eventually a boy with a mirror arrives and delivers the hand mirror to the woman with the feathers. She hands the mirror over to the girl wearing the lion outfit and the woman in the black dress; 05:57 The woman wearing the black dress is now seated in another chair and wearing a white veil. She pulls the sword out of its sheath and raises it in the air; 06:35 Close-up of a wolf mask with grapes hanging out of the mouth. A group of men and women pose with flags and peace signs in a living room. The woman dressed as the lion sits in the middle of the group; 07:55 The three women act out a new scene with the white veil and the hand mirror; 09:00 The camera focuses on an image of an older man. The image slowly appears in the mirror on the wall. The scene changes back to Ann Roy utilizing the mirror; 09:37 The camera zooms in on the painting that was shown at the beginning of the film. There is text at the bottom of the painting that reads, “God is a mother!” Film ends.
